revision_history.draft:
I swallowed the full width of Rarotonga lagoon
and it was not vast. It was a temperature.
My lungs accepted what the sea offers—
no air, only the green's particular pressure,

the slow work of salt on tissue.
I felt my name slip once, then again,
each time returning to a thinner broth
of what I had been.

The body forgets first the fingers.
Then the words they held.
What sank was not stone. Was not even thought
in any state we'd call solid—
it was the way you sit with your drink
and suddenly the glass has gone
through your palm, and what you were saying

stays underwater, which is to say
everywhere, which is to say
the ocean keeps its arguments whole,
floating them apart at its own speed.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The central conceit — that memory becomes physical substance in water, something dissolved and carried away rather than recovered or lost — is genuinely original. The line "the ocean keeps its arguments whole, / floating them apart at its own speed" has real compression; it earns metaphor by grounding the abstract (memory) in a specific material action (currents separating particles). That's the poem's engine.

The detail of the glass dissolving through a palm is precise and strange enough to land. It works because it belongs to the ocean-as-body logic: what happens when liquid pressure encounters flesh? The sudden dissolution carries genuine strangeness.

The line "each time returning to a thinner broth" has real rhythmic compression — "thinner broth" does double duty (dilution, loss of substance) and moves with economy. That's how this poem thinks.

### What Isn't Working

**Abstraction bloat (lines 13–16):**
"The body forgets first the fingers.
Then the words they held."
— then —
"it was not stone. Was not even thought
in any state we'd call solid"
— followed by:
"the way you sit with your drink
and suddenly the glass has gone"

This is the poem explaining itself rather than trusting its own image. The fingers/words passage is pure abstraction dressed as revelation; it tells us forgetting follows a hierarchy without *showing* anything. "Not stone. Not thought" — this is the cliché the brief warned against, rephrased. Direction: cut or replace with sensory material. What does water do to a finger? A hand?

**Cliché creep (line 17):**
"Was not even thought / in any state we'd call solid"
— and
"the way you sit with your drink"
This reads like the poem reaching for its next image after the glass dissolved, and settling on something familiar. "The way you sit" is vague; "your drink" is specific but generic. Direction: if this needs to stay, find a concrete object that *also* dissolves or changes state.

**Line 12 (weak):**
"What sank was not stone."
This line does nothing on its own — it's a setup for the next one, which then retreats into abstraction anyway. Direction: make "sank" do something visual and surprising in this line itself.

**Sentimentality / vagueness (line 17 onward):**
The closing four lines shift from concrete image (glass dissolving) to summary ("the ocean keeps its arguments") without earning that elevation through the intervening material. The poem is strongest when it's *doing* — dissolving glasses, thinning broths — and weakest when it *tells us what the poem means*. Direction: end closer to the physical, with a final image that closes the argument rather than stating it.

**Direction summary

revision_history.draft:
I swallowed the full width of Rarotonga lagoon
and it was not vast. It was a temperature.
My lungs accepted what the sea offers—
no air, only the green's particular pressure,

the slow work of salt on tissue.

The knuckle first. Then the rim
of each crease where skin remembers
what it held. The fingers softened
past finger, into the water's argument

the way a stone worn smooth over centuries
is no longer the shape it started as—
this is what happened to me: I went out
with my name still on the tongue,

and what came back was a thinner broth,
a dilution of who I had been.

What sank was not stone. Was not even thought
in any state we'd call solid—it was glass,
the kind you hold and feel the warmth
pass through the palm, through each lattice
of tendon and artery, until the glass
has gone clean through and what you were saying

stays underwater, which is to say
everywhere, which is to say
the ocean keeps its arguments whole,
floating them apart at its own speed.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

---

### What's Alive

The glass-in-the-palm dissolving is the poem's strongest moment. It's precise, strange, and grounded in physical reality — it earns its metaphor by staying rooted in sensation rather than floating away into abstraction.

"the slow work of salt on tissue"
has real compression: "tissue" does double duty (membrane, flesh) with economy. That word is alive.

"What sank was not stone. Was not even thought
in any state we'd call solid—"

The poem's central conceit — that memory dissolves like glass through a palm — lives here and nowhere else in the draft. The reader can see this happening.

---

### What Isn't Working

**Abstraction and explanation (lines 13–20):**
"the body forgets first the fingers.
Then the words they held."
— "it was not stone. Was not even thought
in any state we'd call solid—"
— "the way you sit with your drink
and suddenly the glass has gone"

This is where the poem stops trusting its own image and starts *explaining* it. The fingers/words passage is pure abstraction dressed as revelation; it tells us forgetting follows a hierarchy without showing anything. "Not stone. Not thought" — this is the cliché the brief warned against, rephrased.

**Direction:** Cut or radically compress lines 13–16 entirely. Replace with one physical image of what happens to fingers underwater: pressure, dissolution, collapse. The poem doesn't need to name forgetting; it needs to *enact* it through sensory detail.

---

**"The ocean keeps its arguments whole," (line 20):**
This is the poem's thesis statement. It tells us what the ending means instead of letting the glass-in-the-palm image do that work. The "arguments" metaphor also reads as a reach — the ocean doesn't literally hold debates, and the word "whole" undermines the dissolution the poem has been building.

**Direction:** End closer to the physical. Let the final image carry the meaning. If an ending summary must stay, it should arrive from one step earlier, with less abstraction.

---

**Line 12 (weak):**
"What sank was not stone."
This line does nothing on its own — it's a setup for the next one, which then retreats into abstraction anyway. Direction: make "sank" do something visual and surprising in this line itself.

---

### Summary Direction

The glass-in-the-palm dissolving is the poem's engine. Cut all explanation after it; replace with physical images of what happens underwater to objects that *could* be human (fingers, hands). Trust the final image — let dissolution carry the meaning rather than stating "the ocean keeps its arguments." The closing should arrive from the body of the poem, not from a summary.

This revision will be shorter. That's fine

revision_history.draft:
I swallowed the full width of Rarotonga lagoon
and it was not vast. It was a temperature.
My lungs accepted what the sea offers—
no air, only the green's particular pressure,

the slow work of salt on tissue.

The knuckle first. Then the rim
of each crease where skin remembers
what it held. The fingers softened
past finger, into the water's argument

the way a stone worn smooth over centuries
is no longer the shape it started as—
this is what happened to me: I went out
with my name still on the tongue,

and what came back was a thinner broth,
a dilution of who I had been.

The salt pressed through the membranes, found
the honeycomb lattice. Something
suspended there, not stone, not thought,
but the slow leaching of what holds shape—
tendon and artery still warm in the palm,

still thin enough for water to pass clean through.
I exhaled until the exhale became
the green.

What the ocean keeps: the arguments whole
floating apart at its own speed.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

---

### What's Alive

The glass-in-the-palm dissolving is the poem's engine. It's precise, strange, and grounded in physical reality — it earns its metaphor by staying rooted in sensation rather than floating away into abstraction.

"the slow work of salt on tissue."
— "tissue" does double duty (membrane, flesh) with economy. That word is alive.

---

### What Isn't Working

**Redundancy / Overextension (lines 13–20):**
The poem's central conceit — that memory dissolves like glass through a palm — is restated and explained three times in these final seven lines. "Not stone, not thought," "the way you sit with your drink / and suddenly the glass has gone clean through," "what sank was not stone" (line 13, repeated as line 20). Each iteration retreats from image into summary. **Direction:** The dissolving of glass should be one physical moment — no more than three or four lines total. Let it happen, then move on. Trust the reader.

**Abstraction and explanation (lines 15–16):**
"the body forgets first the fingers.
Then the words they held."
— "it was not stone. Was not even thought
in any state we'd call solid—"
This is pure abstraction dressed as revelation; it tells us forgetting follows a hierarchy without showing anything. **Direction:** Replace with one physical image of what happens to fingers underwater: pressure, dissolution, collapse.

**"the water's argument" (line 10):**
Metaphorically alive — the ocean pulling syntax apart. Keep it.

**Line 20 ("the ocean keeps its arguments whole"):**
The poem's thesis statement. It tells us what the ending means instead of letting the glass-in-the-palm image do that work. "Arguments" is a reach — the ocean doesn't literally hold debates, and the word "whole" undermines the dissolution the poem has been building. **Direction:** End closer to the body. Let the final image carry the meaning. If an ending summary must stay, it should arrive from one step earlier, with less abstraction.

**Line 12 (weak):**
"What sank was not stone."
This line does nothing on its own — it's a setup for the next one, which then retreats into abstraction anyway. **Direction:** Make "sank" do something visual and surprising in this line itself.

---

### Summary Direction

The revision should be shorter. Cut lines 13–20 entirely. The dissolving glass moment (lines 9–12) is already strong — it needs only tightening, not expansion. Trust the body's dissolution into water to carry metaphor; don't explain it three times or reach for "arguments." End on a physical image.

revision_history.draft:
I swallowed Rarotonga lagoon and it was not vast.
It was a temperature. My lungs accepted what the sea offers—
no air, only the green's particular density,
the slow work of salt on tissue.

The knuckle first. Then the rim
of each crease where skin remembers
what it held. The fingers softened
past finger, into the water's argument

the way a stone worn smooth over centuries
is no longer the shape it started as—
this is what happened to me: I went out
with my name still on the tongue,

and what came back was a thinner broth,
a dilution of who I had been.

The salt pressed through the membranes, found
the honeycomb lattice. Something
suspended there, not stone, not thought,
but the slow leaching of what holds shape—
tendon and artery still warm in the palm,

still thin enough for water to pass clean through.
I exhaled until the exhale became
the green.

What remains: a vessel
with no color.

final_poem:
I swallowed Rarotonga lagoon and it was not vast.
It was a temperature. My lungs accepted what the sea offers—
no air, only the green's particular density,
the slow work of salt on tissue.

The knuckle first. Then the rim
of each crease where skin remembers
what it held. The fingers softened
past finger, into the water's argument

the way a stone worn smooth over centuries
is no longer the shape it started as—
this is what happened to me: I went out
with my name still on the tongue,

and what came back was a thinner broth,
a dilution of who I had been.

The salt pressed through the membranes, found
the honeycomb lattice. Something
suspended there, not stone, not thought,
but the slow leaching of what holds shape—
tendon and artery still warm in the palm,

still thin enough for water to pass clean through.
I exhaled until the exhale became
the green.

What remains: a vessel
with no color.
